I cant burn it to a DVD (that would take forever) and emailing an archive is out of the question. Then it hit me â€“ a while back I installed Dropbox after reading it from a Lifehacker post. With a free 2GB account I can upload the files and the latest backup easy. Later I just have to install the client in my home PC and the sync should be automatic.

I quickly checked my program files. Great! Havenâ€™t uninstalled yet. I open the app. Then copied the files to my designated local dropbox folder. After a minute I see the check icon and done. I apologize for the dramatics. Its a little exaggerated but thatâ€™s really how I come to appreciate this awesome web app.


Dropbox is a storage provider maintained by Everflow Inc. Anyone can register and get 2 gigabytes of Dropbox webspace to play with. It’s not a new wheel but heck it’s free and suprisingly robust. You even have an opportunity to increase your account’s capacity up to 3 gigabytes by inviting others to get their own accounts. Setting up is a breeze, you need to install a small client to handle syncing your local and remote Dropbox folders. After installation, the client will ask you to login your myDropbox account or register for a new one. Login and choose a folder to sync (or just use the default setting) – and that’s that. You now have a simple backup system to keep your mind at ease. Its not just some place you upload files to. The whole system sports a number of features such as a revision history and a means to collaborate files.

Everyone has their own way in keeping their precious files safe and readily available. Dropbox just extends it a bit further with some cool features and for casual users – its free. The only thing i see the client lacking is a means to monitor multiple dropbox folders – not just one. But all in all I love my Dropbox account and highly recommend it to anyone.

Rating

4 stars : Installation

5 stars : Interface

4 stars : Ease of use
